titleInfo.title: Perceived Acceptability, Appropriateness, and Participation Fidelity in a Web-Based Intervention for Error Sensitivity in 5-7-Year-Olds
titleInfo.subTitle: A Mixed-Methods Evaluation

mods:mods.abstract: Error sensitivity, or high reactivity to making mistakes, is an aspect of perfectionism, which confers risk for future anxiety disorders and a range of other poor mental health outcomes in youth. Preliminary research has shown that perfectionism and error sensitivity can be reduced in youth via psychosocial interventions. Pilot data from our own research group have also shown that a brief digital health intervention can reduce error sensitivity in young children who have an elevated response to errors. Despite initial evidence for efficacy of psychosocial and digital health interventions in decreasing error sensitivity and perfectionism, these programs are unlikely to effect change on a large scale without proper consideration of the implementation context, and incorporation of consumer perspectives. The present study evaluated the implementation and engagement outcomes associated with a novel, digital-health preventive intervention program targeting error sensitivity in children aged 5 to 7 years that is currently being tested in a randomized controlled trial. Intervention topics include providing psychoeducation on error sensitivity, responding positively to mistakes, modeling positive reactions to mistakes, challenging yourself, listening to your "mistake buddy" and not your "mistake bully", and making mistakes on purpose. The present study used quantitative and qualitative methods to examine the implementation characteristics of this novel intervention program, including perceived acceptability, appropriateness, and participation fidelity. Quantitatively, both parents and children self-reported high perceived acceptability and appropriateness at two time points. Participants adhered to just over one third of the weekly modules on average. Coded transcripts from semi-structured interviews conducted with parents and children (18 parents, 14 children) were thematically analyzed, yielding four themes: Content Embraced and Implemented, Acceptable Delivery with Room for Improvement, Diverse Family Characteristics and Needs, and Positive Changes. Qualitative data revealed the program to be acceptable and appropriate to parents and children, with somewhat more variability in perceived appropriateness. Participation fidelity was variable with respect to the proportion of weekly activities completed, timing of completing the weekly activities, and enactment of strategies learned. Participants provided useful feedback regarding the program content, delivery, engagement strategies, and desired dose of intervention. Barriers and facilitators of engagement were also identified, which pertained to program and family characteristics. The intervention components of psychoeducation, responding positively to errors, modeling positive reactions to mistakes, and parent-child interactive activities emerged as essential components of the program. Results suggest that the novel, preventive digital-health intervention targeting error sensitivity is largely acceptable and appropriate to families, and that further refinement of the program may enhance the program's implementation potential (e.g., further gamify the program, create a mobile app, increase customizability, include additional content modules and examples). Results also have implications for other digital-health interventions, preventive programs, programs targeting error sensitivity or perfectionism, psychosocial interventions for parent-child dyads, programs for preschool-aged children, and qualitative methodologies with young children.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
children, digital mental health intervention, engagement, parenting, perfectionism, qualitative

Alexandria Meyer, Professor Directing Dissertation; Lyndsay N. Jenkins, University Representative; Michael J. Kofler, Committee Member; Walter R. Boot, Committee Member; Anne E. Barrett, Committee Member.
